greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of subsets of divisors of n having equal sums as their complements.
comment: a(n)=0 for deficient numbers n (A005100), but the converse is not true, as 18 is abundant (A005101) and a(18)=0, see A083211;
a(n)=1 for perfect numbers n (A000396), see A083209 for all numbers with a(n)=1;

In order that a(n)>0, the sum of divisors of n must be even by definition: a(n) = half the number of partitions of A000203(n)/2 into divisors of n, see formula. [From _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 10 2010]
link: T. D. Noe and R. Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..10000
Reinhard Zumkeller, Illustration of initial terms
formula: a(n) = if sigma(n) mod 2 = 1 then 0 else f(n,sigma(n)/2,2), where sigma=A000203 and f(n,m,k) = if k<=m then f(n,m,k+1)+f(n,m-k,k+1)*0^(n mod k) else 0^m, cf. A033630, also using f. [From _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 10 2010]
mathematica: a[n_] := (s = DivisorSigma[1, n]; If[Mod[s, 2] == 1, 0, f[n, s/2, 2]]); f[n_, m_, k_] := f[n, m, k] = If[k <= m, f[n, m, k+1] + f[n, m-k, k+1]*Boole[Mod[n, k] == 0], Boole[m == 0]]; Array[a, 105] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 29 2015, after _Reinhard Zumkeller_ *)
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 22 2003
